entities.title: Ferenc Pfaff
entities.description: Ferenc Pfaff was a Hungarian architect and academic.

entities.title: Zagreb Central Station
entities.description: Zagreb Glavni kolodvor is the main railway station in Zagreb. Located 1 km (0.62 mi) south of the city's main square, it is the largest station in Croatia and the main hub of the Croatian Railways network.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Downer, Australian politician, 16th Premier of South Australia (b. 1843)

entities.title: John Downer
entities.description: Sir John William Downer, KCMG, KC was an Australian politician who served two terms as Premier of South Australia, from 1885 to 1887 and again from 1892 to 1893. He later entered federal politics and served as a Senator for South Australia from 1901 to 1903. He was the first of four Australian politicians from the Downer family dynasty.

entities.title: Premier of South Australia
entities.description: The Premier of South Australia is the head of government in the state of South Australia, Australia. The Government of South Australia follows the Westminster system, with a Parliament of South Australia acting as the legislature. The Premier is appointed by the Governor of South Australia, and by modern convention holds office by virtue of his or her ability to command the support of a majority o

heading: Deaths
txt: Jaan Mahlapuu, Estonian military pilot (b. 1894)

entities.title: Jaan Mahlapuu
entities.description: Jaan Mahlapuu was an Estonian fighter pilot for the Imperial Russian Air Service in World War I. He is known for being the first ace of Estonian origin.

heading: Deaths
txt: Enrico Caruso, Italian tenor and actor (b. 1873)

entities.title: Enrico Caruso
entities.description: Enrico Caruso was an Italian operatic tenor. He sang to great acclaim at the major opera houses of Europe and the Americas, appearing in a wide variety of roles (74) from the Italian and French repertoires that ranged from the lyric to the dramatic. One of the first major singing talents to be commercially recorded, Caruso made 247 commercially released recordings from 1902 to 1920, which made him

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Graham Bell, Scottish-Canadian engineer, invented the telephone (b. 1847)

entities.title: Alexander Graham Bell
entities.description: Alexander Graham Bell was a Scottish-born inventor, scientist, and engineer who is credited with inventing and patenting the first practical telephone. He also co-founded the American Telephone and Telegraph Company (AT&T) in 1885.

entities.title: Telephone
entities.description: A telephone is a telecommunications device that permits two or more users to conduct a conversation when they are too far apart to be heard directly. A telephone converts sound, typically and most efficiently the human voice, into electronic signals that are transmitted via cables and other communication channels to another telephone which reproduces the sound to the receiving user. The term is de

heading: Deaths
txt: Warren G. Harding, American journalist and politician, 29th President of the United States (b. 1865)

entities.title: Warren G. Harding
entities.description: Warren Gamaliel Harding was the 29th president of the United States, serving from 1921 until his death in 1923. A member of the Republican Party, he was one of the most popular U.S. presidents to that point. After his death, a number of scandals, including Teapot Dome, came to light, as did his extramarital affair with Nan Britton; those eroded his popular regard.

entities.title: President of the United States
entities.description: The president of the United States (POTUS) is the head of state and head of government of the United States of America. The president directs the executive branch of the federal government and is the commander-in-chief of the United States Armed Forces.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul von Hindenburg, German field marshal and politician, 2nd President of Germany (b. 1847)

entities.title: Paul von Hindenburg
entities.description: Paul Ludwig Hans Anton von Beneckendorff und von Hindenburg, was a German general and statesman who led the Imperial German Army during World War I and later became President of Germany from 1925 until his death in 1934. During his presidency, he played a key role in the Nazi seizure of power in January 1933 when, under pressure from advisers, he appointed Adolf Hitler as Chancellor of Germany.

entities.title: President of Germany
entities.description: The president of Germany, officially the Federal President of the Federal Republic of Germany, is the head of state of Germany.

heading: Deaths
txt: Artur Sirk, Estonian soldier, lawyer, and politician (b. 1900)

entities.title: Artur Sirk
entities.description: Artur Sirk was an Estonian political and military figure. A veteran of the country's struggle for independence Sirk later became a leading figure within the right-wing Vaps Movement and an outspoken opponent of the government.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harvey Spencer Lewis, American mystic and author (b. 1883)

entities.title: Harvey Spencer Lewis
entities.description: Harvey Spencer Lewis F.R.C., S:::I:::I:::, 33° 66° 95°, PhD, a noted Rosicrucian author, occultist, and mystic, was the founder in the USA and the first Imperator of the Ancient and Mystical Order Rosae Crucis (AMORC), from 1915 until 1939.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pietro Mascagni, Italian composer and educator (b. 1863)

entities.title: Pietro Mascagni
entities.description: Pietro Mascagni was an Italian composer primarily known for his operas. His 1890 masterpiece Cavalleria rusticana caused one of the greatest sensations in opera history and single-handedly ushered in the Verismo movement in Italian dramatic music. While it was often held that Mascagni, like Ruggiero Leoncavallo, was a "one-opera man" who could never repeat his first success, L'amico Fritz and Iris

heading: Deaths
txt: Alfred Lépine, Canadian ice hockey player and coach (b. 1901)

entities.title: Alfred Lépine
entities.description: Joseph Alfred Pierre Hormisdas "Pit" Lépine was a Canadian ice hockey forward and coach. He was born in Sainte-Anne-de-Bellevue, Quebec.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wallace Stevens, American poet and educator (b. 1879)

heading: Deaths
txt: Oliver La Farge, American anthropologist and author (b. 1901)

entities.title: Oliver La Farge
entities.description: Oliver Hazard Perry La Farge II was an American writer and anthropologist. During 1925 he explored early Olmec sites in Mexico, and later studied additional sites in Central America and the American Southwest. In addition to more than 15 scholarly works, mostly about Native Americans, he wrote several novels, including the Pulitzer Prize-winning, Laughing Boy (1929). La Farge also wrote and publis

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Terence Stace, English-American epistemologist, philosopher, and academic (b. 1886)

entities.title: Walter Terence Stace
entities.description: Walter Terence Stace was a British civil servant, educator, public philosopher and epistemologist, who wrote on Hegel, mysticism, and moral relativism. He worked with the Ceylon Civil Service from 1910 to 1932, and from 1932 to 1955 he was employed by Princeton University in the Department of Philosophy. He is most renowned for his work in the philosophy of mysticism, and for books like Mysticism

heading: Deaths
txt: Angus MacFarlane-Grieve, English academic, mathematician, rower, and soldier (b. 1891)

entities.title: Angus MacFarlane-Grieve
entities.description: Alexander Angus MacFarlane-Grieve, was a British academic, mathematician, rower, and decorated British Army officer. He served with the Highland Light Infantry during World War I. He was Master of University College, Durham from 1939 to 1954, and additionally Master of Hatfield College, Durham from 1940 to 1949.

heading: Deaths
txt: Brian Cole, American bass player (b. 1942)

entities.title: Brian Cole
entities.description: Brian Cole was the bass guitar player and one of the founding members of the 1960s folk rock band the Association.

heading: Deaths
txt: Helen Hoyt, American poet and author (b. 1887)

entities.title: Jean-Pierre Melville
entities.description: Jean-Pierre Melville was a French filmmaker and actor.

heading: Deaths
txt: Douglas Hawkes, English race car driver and businessman (b. 1893)

entities.title: Douglas Hawkes
entities.description: Wallace Douglas Hawkes was a British motor car designer, businessman and racing driver. He was born in Barton, Gloucestershire, and died, aged 80, in Athens, Greece.

heading: Deaths
txt: László Kalmár, Hungarian mathematician and academic (b. 1905)

entities.title: László Kalmár
entities.description: László Kalmár was a Hungarian mathematician and Professor at the University of Szeged. Kalmár is considered the founder of mathematical logic and theoretical computer science in Hungary.

txt: Fritz Lang, Austrian-American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1890)

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlos Chávez, Mexican composer and conductor (b. 1899)

entities.title: Carlos Chávez
entities.description: Carlos Antonio de Padua Chávez y Ramírez was a Mexican composer, conductor, music theorist, educator, journalist, and founder and director of the Mexican Symphonic Orchestra. He was influenced by native Mexican cultures. Of his six symphonies, the second, or Sinfonía india, which uses native Yaqui percussion instruments, is probably the most popular.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antony Noghès, French businessman, founded the Monaco Grand Prix (b. 1890)

entities.title: Monaco Grand Prix
entities.description: The Monaco Grand Prix is a Formula One motor racing event held annually on the Circuit de Monaco on the last weekend in May. Run since 1929, it is widely considered to be one of the most important and prestigious automobile races in the world, and is one of the races—along with the Indianapolis 500 and the 24 Hours of Le Mans—that form the Triple Crown of Motorsport. The circuit has been called "a

heading: Deaths
txt: Thurman Munson, American baseball player (b. 1947)

entities.title: Thurman Munson
entities.description: Thurman Lee Munson was an American professional baseball catcher who played 11 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) with the New York Yankees, from 1969 until his death in 1979. A seven-time All-Star, Munson had a career batting average of .292 with 113 home runs and 701 runs batted in (RBIs). Known for his outstanding fielding, he won the Gold Glove Award in three consecutive years (1973–75).

heading: Deaths
txt: Stefanie Clausen, Danish diver (b. 1900)

entities.title: Stefanie Clausen
entities.description: Anna Stefanie Nanna Fryland Clausen was a Danish diver. She was a gold medalist at the 1920 Summer Olympics.

heading: Deaths
txt: James Jamerson, American bass player (b. 1936)

entities.title: James Jamerson
entities.description: James Lee Jamerson was an American bass player. He was the uncredited bassist on most of the Motown Records hits in the 1960s and early 1970s, and is now regarded as one of the most influential bass players in modern music history. heading: Deaths
txt: Roy Cohn, American lawyer and politician (b. 1927)

entities.title: Roy Cohn
entities.description: Roy Marcus Cohn was an American lawyer who came to prominence for his role as Senator Joseph McCarthy's chief counsel during the Army–McCarthy hearings in 1954, when he assisted McCarthy's investigations of suspected communists. heading: Deaths

entities.title: Joe Carcione
entities.description: Joseph Carcione was a consumer advocate known as "The Green Grocer."

entities.description: Norman Fitzroy Maclean was an American author and scholar noted for his books A River Runs Through It and Other Stories (1976) and Young Men and Fire (1992).

entities.title: Michel Berger
entities.description: Michel Berger was a French singer and songwriter. He was a figure of France's pop music scene for two decades as a singer and as a songwriter for such artists as Françoise Hardy, Johnny Hallyday, and his wife, France Gall. He died of a heart attack at the age of 44.

heading: Deaths
txt: Michel Debré, French lawyer and politician, 150th Prime Minister of France (b. 1912)

entities.title: Michel Debré
entities.description: Michel Jean-Pierre Debré was the first Prime Minister of the French Fifth Republic. He is considered the "father" of the current Constitution of France. He served under President Charles de Gaulle from 1959 to 1962. In terms of political personality, he was intense and immovable, with a tendency to rhetorical extremism.

entities.title: Prime Minister of France
entities.description: The prime minister of the French Republic, sometimes shortened to premier, is the head of government of France. During the Third and Fourth Republics, the head of government was formally called president of the Council of Ministers, generally shortened to president of the Council. entities.description: The president of Somalia is the head of state of Somalia. The president is also commander-in-chief of the Somali Armed Forces. The president represents the Federal Republic of Somalia, and the unity of the Somali nation, as well as ensuring the implementation of the Constitution of Somalia and the organised and harmonious functioning of the organs of state. entities.description: William Seward Burroughs II was an American writer, visual artist, spoken word performer and chaos magician credited as a primary figure of the Beat Generation and a major postmodern author who influenced popular culture and literature. txt: Shari Lewis, American television host and puppeteer (b. 1933)

entities.title: Shari Lewis
entities.description: Shari Lewis was an American ventriloquist, puppeteer, children's entertainer, comedian, and television show host. She was best known as the original puppeteer of the sock puppet Lamb Chop, first appearing on Captain Kangaroo in March 1956 and then Hi Mom, a local morning television show that aired on WRCA-TV in New York City.

entities.title: Willie Morris
entities.description: William Weaks Morris was an American writer and editor born in Jackson, Mississippi, though his family later moved to Yazoo City, Mississippi, which he immortalized in his works of prose. Morris' trademark was his lyrical prose style and reflections on the American South, particularly the Mississippi Delta. In 1967 he became the youngest editor of Harper's Magazine. entities.title: Peter Safar
entities.description: Peter Safar was an Austrian anesthesiologist of Czech descent. He is credited with pioneering cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR).

heading: Deaths
txt: Steven Vincent, American journalist and author (b. 1955)

entities.title: Steven Vincent
entities.description: Steven Charles Vincent was an American author and journalist. In 2005 he was working as a freelance journalist in Basra, Iraq, reporting for The Christian Science Monitor, National Review, Mother Jones, Reason, Front Page and American Enterprise, among other publications, when he was abducted and murdered in southern Iraq after investigating corruption by Shia militias.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chauncey Bailey, American journalist (b. 1950)

entities.title: Chauncey Bailey
entities.description: Chauncey Wendell Bailey Jr. was an American journalist noted for his work primarily on issues of the African American community. He served as editor-in-chief of The Oakland Post in Oakland, California from June 2007 until his murder. His 37-year career in journalism included lengthy periods as a reporter at The Detroit News and The Oakland Tribune.

txt: José Sanchis Grau, Spanish author and illustrator (b. 1932)

entities.title: José Sanchis Grau
entities.description: José Sanchis Grau was a Spanish comic book writer. He also worked for Editorial Bruguera and Spanish children comics in general. He was the creator of strips like Pumby (1954) and Robín Robot (1972).

entities.title: Nobel Prize
entities.description: The Nobel Prize is not a single prize but five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to ”those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.”

heading: Deaths
txt: Judith Jones, American literary and cookbook editor (b. 1924)

entities.title: Judith Jones
entities.description: Judith Jones was an American writer and editor, best known for having rescued The Diary of Anne Frank from the reject pile. Jones also championed Julia Child's Mastering the Art of French Cooking. She retired as senior editor and vice president at Alfred A. Knopf in 2011. Jones was also a cookbook author and memoirist. heading: Deaths
txt: Suzanne Perlman, Hungarian-Dutch visual artist (b. 1922)

entities.title: Suzanne Perlman
entities.description: Suzanne Perlman was a Hungarian-Dutch visual artist known for her expressionist portraits and landscape paintings. Her bold use of colour has its origins in her early paintings of the tropical island of Curaçao, where she moved with her husband in 1940 to escape Nazi persecution.
